data.title: Fixed the DisplayMode Ordering so it orders the display modes from smallest to highest.
data.body:
XNA seems to report the DisplayModes in size order from small to large.
So the largest is at the end of the list. This commit makes sure that
we do the same.

data.title: Added support for getting "Special" Keys like Backspace.
data.body:
The previous implementation of TextInput did not allow for
special keys to be processed. As a result we missed those keys
which makes it harder to implement things like textboxes.
(Backspace is kinda important).

data.title: Linux Installer Update
data.body:
Stuff done:
- if any previous version is detected the installer will try to find an uninstall script and uninstall it
- added "monogame-uninstall" command for easier uninstallation
- MonoGame Pipeline > MonoGame Pipeline Tool name change
- monogame-pipeline > monogame-pipeline-tool command change
- dependencies are now getting checked like in the screenshoot bellow

data.title: Index/VertexBuffer.OpenGL GetBufferData
SetVertexBuffers and DrawInstancedPrimitives for OpenGL
data.body:
I'm getting into OpenGL a bit, and to get some hands on experience I'm trying to implement SetVertexBuffers and DrawInstancedPrimitives (takes care of #913) and I was wondering if the PR for that should just go here or in @cra0zy's SDL2 branch (because there might be some annoying conflicts?). I got it working with multiple vertex buffers, but I can't test DrawInstancedPrimitives right now because I'm on Linux (shader compilation). I'll try Windows and instanced drawing tomorrow.

I'm also unsure if instanced drawing is available on all platforms that MonoGame supports. I think it works on ES 2.0 only with a certain extension and I'm not sure about Windows Phone either. Should I do some checks for that? Anyways, that's probably easier to discuss when the PR is up, so tl;dr where should the PR go?

data.title: Replace OpenTK with custom bindings for DesktopGL
data.body:
Cleaned out version of #4555

CC. @dellis1972 @mrhelmut

data.title: [Documentation] Fix some minor typos in XML docs
Use xwt for ProjectControl?
data.body:
As you might have noticed ProjectControl is really dirty:
- https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/Tools/Pipeline/Controls/ProjectControl.win.cs
- https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/Tools/Pipeline/Controls/ProjectControl.gtk.cs
- https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/Tools/Pipeline/Controls/ProjectControl.mac.cs

This is because Eto.Forms doesn't have a good multiselect treeview control. Now instead of using the one from Eto.Forms we could use the Xwt one. This would allow us to:
- have same code for this control between platforms
- gain same drag and drop code, Eto.Forms doesn't support drag and drop, Xwt does

Negative side effects?
- Pipeline Tool for Windows will need to use WPF since Xwt doesn't support Windows Forms

I really wish that I thought of this idea earlier... at least I didn't start writing the new DnD code yet.

cc. @tomspilman @KonajuGames @dellis1972

data.title: What about Shared Project Template?
data.body:
In the Xamarin Forms, Everybody can make the Shared Project with Android, iOS, UWP. How about like-this template for MonoGame in MonoGame Installer?

This template will have a advantage about Cross-platform Game Development. Shared Code, Shared Content.mgcb, Each Platform Projects.

I tried this manually, It is so annoying works. I want to create projects and settings automatically. And It is reason what want to this template.

P.S. If MonoGame Community are discussing about Portable Class Library, What about Shared Project? Shared Project is more easy to building and using right?

data.title: Properly setting the LeftTrigger and RightTrigger buttons in UWP
data.body:
There's no code that could possibly set Buttons.LeftTrigger or Buttons.RightTrigger in UWP mode. This code is similar to: https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Input/GamePad.XInput.cs#L251

I tested this in a Windows Universal app using an Xbox 360 Controller and an Xbox One Controller.

data.title: [SDL] General Improvements
data.body:
This is a set of minor improvements, it includes:
- fix the mouse state for < 2.0.4 SDL version
- implement resizable function (only available via the custom patch provided by @flibitijibibo, repo for SDL is at https://github.com/FNA-XNA/SDL-mirror)
  - add a version check using that function since the current devel version is reporting 2.0.4 anyway

data.title: .NET Native Content pipeline issue
data.body:
I've been having issues for months now getting the content to build in my Windows 10 Universal project using the .NET Native toolchain. I recently started a thread on the forums here:

http://community.monogame.net/t/custom-content-pipeline-serialization-issues-in-windows-10/7665/3

I finally tracked the issue down to this line of code: https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Content/ContentExtensions.cs#L37

It looks like it's trying to filter out properties on the object that have been hidden using the "new" keyword in C#. Unfortunately, the trick of checking if the GetMethods for the properties are reference equal doesn't seem to work using the .NET Native toolchain. In general, this doesn’t feel like a great way to make this check. The result is that most custom content loads up with blank or null values, which causes crashes elsewhere. 

For my game, I just commented out that line and everything works fine. I don't do any property hiding, although I'm not sure if things would break outright even if I did. Regardless, I spent some time investigating fixes to the problem and it turns out .NET doesn't really have a great way to determine if one property is hiding another in a base class. Especially in the RT environment where reflection is limited. If possible, it seems like it might be best to not do this check at all. I’m not sure what, if anything, was actually breaking downstream before this check existed. Like I said, my project works fine without it. 

To find out why this code exists in the first place, I tried to track down the original commit, but haven't had much luck. I think there have been some git history rewrite shenanigans going on. You can see that in this commit (https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/commit/560741319e82c396049def24e2fdaa32d39e58cf) the logic was moved from ReflectiveReader.cs to ContentExtensions.cs. 

But if you go through the history of ReflectiveReader.cs, you won't see that commit. Also, I can't find any trace of the property hiding check ever having been in that file. Instead you can see the changed seems to have happened between this commit (https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/commit/b940c0d9a289f191e08a17137c06290ebb4a18a2) and this commit (https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/commit/c99103b5e435a15fa24b0ea89f9bf4b2261f35a9)

TLDR; 
The check for property hiding is sketchball and breaks .NET Native apps. .NET doesn’t provide a great way to check for this at all. Maybe you should kill it altogether. 

PS: The GetAllProperties() and GetAllFields() functions are misnamed. They both get very restrictive sets of properties/fields.

data.title: Fix for "Input string was not in a correct format."
data.body: Using `TryParse` solves the problem when name is just `BlendIndicies` for example, in which case we default to index 0, assuming only 1 index.

data.title: [Pipeline Tool] Fix null reference exception with Windows propertygrid dialog launching
data.body: The reason why null ref exception would occur is because when a new dialog is created it will pause the current drawing, and create a new redraw event to show the dialog, but the new redraw event will reset `_selectedCell` to `null` since mouse is out of focus, and since the old event didn't finish up `_edit` would still be `true`.

data.title: Three fixes for basic errors
data.body: Some errors I encountered while trying to use the develop build today.

data.title: fxaa.fx(439,16) : Unexpected token ',' found. Expected Semicolon - This was working previously.
data.body:
Hi after upgrading to the latest Monogame, my FXAA shader no longer compiles. I get this output from the pipeline tool:

```
Build started 20/05/2016 16:17:34

C:/Users/a/Content/Shaders/fxaa.fx
C:/Users/a/Content/Shaders/fxaa.fx: C:\Users\a\Content\Shaders\fxaa.fx(80,18) : Unexpected token ',' found. Expected Semicolon
C:\Users\a\Content\Shaders\fxaa.fx(439,18) : Unexpected token ',' found. Expected Semicolon


Build 0 succeeded, 1 failed.

Time elapsed 00:00:00.87.
```

From the shader, these are the locations it references:

```
float4 FxaaPixelShader_PC(
    float2 pos,
    sampler2D tex, // <-- this comma
    float2 fxaaQualityRcpFrame,
    float fxaaQualitySubpix,
    float fxaaQualityEdgeThreshold,
    float fxaaQualityEdgeThresholdMin)
{
```

and

```
float4 FxaaPixelShader_Console(
    float2 pos,
    float4 fxaaConsolePosPos, 
    sampler2D tex, // <-- this comma
    float4 fxaaConsoleRcpFrameOpt,
    float4 fxaaConsoleRcpFrameOpt2,
    float fxaaConsoleEdgeSharpness,
    float fxaaConsoleEdgeThreshold, 
    float fxaaConsoleEdgeThresholdMin) 
{
```

data.title: Fixes potential stencil state mismatch
data.body:
When resolving a multisampled rendertarget, we have to disable the stencil test to make sure everything is resolved properly.
The way it was previously done was to directly call `GL.Disable(EnableCap.ScissorTest)` and we set `GraphicsDevice._depthStencilStateDirty = true` to ensure the current stencil test value was returned to its original value during the next draw call.
Unfortunately this fails if `GraphicsDevice._lastDepthStencilState.StencilEnable == GraphicsDevice.DepthStencilState.StencilEnable == true` since MonoGame caches state and makes sure to not submit superfluous OpenGL calls. In that case, the stencil test would not be reset to its original state (the one before the rendertarget gets resolved).

The fix is very simple and explicit: it tests the value of the last **applied** stencil state and only disable it if necessary, and reenable it right after if it was previously enabled.

Despite being the original author of the multisampling code, I have no idea why it wasn't done this way in the first place. Apologies if this sneaky bug caused you as much pain as it did for us :)

data.body:
Related to #1455.
At this time I have implemented some tests for `Texture2D.SetData()` with 1 and 3 parameters, the other overloads will come later. If someone reads the code, the testCases are grouped from bottom to top as follows: XNA and Monogame passed tests, only Monogame passed tests, and failing tests.

Things pending:
- Add tests for the remaining `SetData` overloads.
- Separate the TestCases if they should pass or fail
- Fix issues found in the Monogame implementation

data.title: [dev/Pipeline] add existing item (with missing item from project) => invalid URI exception
data.body:
Existing item cannot be added to a project in pipeline tool (new item, new folder, add folder works):

> System.UriFormatException: URI non valide : Impossible de déterminer le format de l'URI.
>    à System.Uri.CreateThis(String uri, Boolean dontEscape, UriKind uriKind)
>    à MonoGame.Tools.Pipeline.MainWindow.ChooseContentFile(String initialDirectory, List`1& files) dans C:\MonoGame\Tools\Pipeline\MainWindow.cs:ligne 204
>    à MonoGame.Tools.Pipeline.PipelineController.Include() dans C:\MonoGame\Tools\Pipeline\Common\PipelineController.cs:ligne 610
>    à MonoGame.Tools.Pipeline.MainWindow.CmdExistingItem_Executed(Object sender, EventArgs e) dans C:\MonoGame\Tools\Pipeline\MainWindow.cs:ligne 527
>    à Eto.Forms.Command.OnExecuted(EventArgs e)
>    à Eto.Forms.Command.System.Windows.Input.ICommand.Execute(Object parameter)
>    à Eto.Forms.ToolItem.OnClick(EventArgs e)
>    à System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripItem.RaiseEvent(Object key, EventArgs e)
>    à System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripButton.OnClick(EventArgs e)
>    à System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripItem.HandleClick(EventArgs e)
>    à System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripItem.HandleMouseUp(MouseEventArgs e)
>    à System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip.OnMouseUp(MouseEventArgs mea)
>    à System.Windows.Forms.Control.WmMouseUp(Message& m, MouseButtons button, Int32 clicks)
>    à System.Windows.Forms.Control.WndProc(Message& m)
>    à System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip.WndProc(Message& m)
>    à Eto.WinForms.Forms.ToolBar.ToolStripEx.WndProc(Message& m)
>    à System.Windows.Forms.NativeWindow.Callback(IntPtr hWnd, Int32 msg, IntPtr wparam, IntPtr lparam)

MonoGame and Pipeline build today from a git dev repository sync'ed just yesterday, on windows 7 64b, using windows platform build.

I've also do the same as given in issue #4851 regarding submodule, just in case and rebuild all, same results.

Update: it's happened with an old dummy project, creating a new one, clean, is ok.
Here is the file: [badproject.zip](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/files/265795/badproject.zip)

Some items are missing, they have been deleted since, so the steps to get the issue are:
- create a project, 
- add an asset from a given location,
- close the project,
- delete the asset in project folder
- open the project file
- click on "add an existing item"

data.title: Fix SDL Game Window Resize
data.body:
For some reason SDL seems to sometimes report multipe resize
events with the same width and height. This can cause problems
for game if they are doing things like creating render targets
in the event.

So we need to make sure we only call the event when we actually change
the width or height.

data.title: referencing pipeline.Windows in a project using windowsGL
data.body:
I have a VS solution where I am including all the project files that my game requires.
![solution explorer](http://i.imgur.com/MfA0lv1.png)

When using the `protobuild.exe --generate windowsgl` command, it does not produce pipeline tool projects for the windowsGL vs2015 solution generated. So when if my game is targeting windowsGL I have to type  `protobuild.exe --generate windows` to get the required project files. 

The pipeline tool projects created reference the MonoGame.Framework.Windows. 

I would like a version of the pipeline tools that references MonoGame.Framework.WindowsGL. Is this possible or does the tool require something that WindowsGL does not provide?

data.title: [Pipeline Tool] PropertyGrid Integrated Combobox
data.body: Needs: https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame.Dependencies/pull/83

data.title: Added support for KeyDown/Up to the GameWindow.
data.body:
XNA was missing some Key input features which make
implementing text boxes a bit easier. One of these
new features was the TextInput event on the game
window. However this only gave us access to characters
that were pressed.

This commit adds a new KeyDown/Up events which give us
access to the actual keypress events. This will allow
for better text input control.

Users can now do

```
window.KeyDown += delegate (s, e) => {
    if (e.Key == Keys.Back)
        // Handle the Back key
};
```

Note this does NOT replace the Keyboard.GetState and it should
only really be used when trying to capture keyboard input for
TextInput.

data.title: Remove Redundant code for checking Pitch range.
data.body:
We check the values that Pitch is being set too in the
setter of the property. There is no need for this additional
check.

data.title: SetRenderTarget garbage reduction
data.body:
Resolves #4843 as per @KonajuGames advice

Also fixes a little typo in `SetRenderTarget(RenderTargetCube)` where it called `SetRenderTarget(RenderTarget2D)` instead of `SetRenderTargets` when the render target was null. It still actually worked, it just meant that it went through another unnecessary method call to get there.

data.title: XAct seems to have a large range for Pitch values that "normal" XNA does.
data.body: So we need to allow a wider range when dealing with values from XAct
